<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
- test_code: a modified metal_shmem_try_map code that contains useful probe functions that print useful logs to a file "/tmp/logs/7.txt". The logs should contain the control path and state information of the violation scenario. If the MISRA C rule is not violated, you can just return an empty string for the test code.
Here are the constraints for the test code:
- DO NOT introduce new violations to demonstrate your scenario.
- The test code MUST be compilable and executable.
- The test code MUST include line breaks.
- The test code MUST preserve the original logic of metal_shmem_try_map as much as possible.
- You MUST NOT define the main function.
- You MUST NOT define macros.
- The test code MUST not contain any mock functions.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_shmem_try_map:
```c
static int metal_shmem_try_map(struct metal_page_size *ps, int fd, size_t size,
			       struct metal_io_region **result)
{
	size_t pages, page, phys_size;
	struct metal_io_region *io;
	metal_phys_addr_t *phys;
	uint8_t *virt;
	void *mem;
	int error;

	size = metal_align_up(size, ps->page_size);
	pages = size / ps->page_size;

	error = metal_map(fd, 0, size, 1, ps->mmap_flags, &mem);
	if (error) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING,
			  "failed to mmap shmem %ld,0x%x - %s\n",
			  size, ps->mmap_flags, strerror(-error));
		return error;
	}

	error = mlock(mem, size);
	if (error) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING, "failed to mlock shmem - %s\n",
			  strerror(errno));
	}

	phys_size = sizeof(*phys) * pages;
	phys = malloc(phys_size);
	if (!phys) {
		metal_unmap(mem, size);
		return -ENOMEM;
	}

	io = malloc(sizeof(*io));
	if (!io) {
		free(phys);
		metal_unmap(mem, size);
		return -ENOMEM;
	}

	if (_metal.pagemap_fd < 0) {
		phys[0] = 0;
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING,
		"shmem - failed to get va2pa mapping. use offset as pa.\n");
		metal_io_init(io, mem, phys, size, -1, 0, &metal_shmem_io_ops);
	} else {
		for (virt = mem, page = 0; page < pages; page++) {
			size_t offset = page * ps->page_size;

			error = metal_virt2phys(virt + offset, &phys[page]);
			if (error < 0)
				phys[page] = METAL_BAD_OFFSET;
		}
		metal_io_init(io, mem, phys, size, ps->page_shift, 0,
			&metal_shmem_io_ops);
	}
	*result = io;

	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_shmem_try_map:
int metal_map(int fd, off_t offset, size_t size, int expand, int flags,
	      void **result)
{
	int prot = PROT_READ | PROT_WRITE, error;
	void *mem;

	flags |= MAP_SHARED;

	if (fd < 0) {
		fd = -1;
		flags = MAP_PRIVATE | MAP_ANONYMOUS;
	} else if (expand) {
		off_t reqsize = offset + size;
		struct stat stat;

		error = flock(fd, LOCK_EX) < 0 ? -errno : 0;
		if (!error)
			error = fstat(fd, &stat);
		if (!error && stat.st_size < reqsize)
			error = ftruncate(fd, reqsize);
		if (!error)
			flock(fd, LOCK_UN);
		if (error)
			return -errno;
	}

	mem = mmap(NULL, size, prot, flags, fd, offset);
	if (mem == MAP_FAILED)
		return -errno;
	*result = mem;
	return 0;
}

#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})

Judge whether the above metal_shmem_try_map code violates the rule 21.17 or not.
scenario: No violation: the function does not call any of the buffer-manipulating functions from <string.h> (e.g., memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn). The only string-related function used is strerror, which takes an integer error code and returns a pointer to an internal message; it does not accept a caller-supplied pointer to a buffer and therefore cannot cause out-of-bounds accesses of caller objects as described by MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. The other operations in the function (mmap, mlock, malloc, loops over pages) do not invoke <string.h> functions that operate on buffers, so the rule is not violated.
